title: Machine Learning for Systems Biosciences

author: Sašo Džeroski, Department of Intelligent Systems, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: The topic machine learning for Systems Biosciences is what probably best describes the research going on in my group, and I'll try to briefly describe what we have been doing in this area over over the last period.
So machine learning by now, you know.
It's very active research area of artificial intelligence.
It studies computer programs that learn from experience, and it has grown tremendously over the last couple of decades and now encompasses a large number of sub areas which include.
Data mining mainly concerned with predictive modeling.
Learning models like decision trees and classification rules.

Then we have reinforcement learning and a kind of a minority topic of computational scientific discovery, which, among other things, considers differential equations as a formalism for representing knowledge.
No systems Biosciences include Sciences like systems biology, which is a fairly new branch of life Sciences and studies.
Biological systems at the micro level studies cellular processes, on the other hand, it includes system psychology, which is a branch of environmental Sciences and studies.
The behavioral systems at the macro level.
Populations within ecosystems, for example, and what they have both in common, is that they study these systems in a holistic manner.
Not focusing only on individual components but also and often primarily on their interactions and the other thing which they have in common is that modeling plays a very important role in both.
And here is the contact point with machine learning which can be used for.
For automated modeling, the research agenda of my group is that we work on development of machine methods.

That's the kind of primary search area, and this include predictive modeling methods, primarily for predicting structured outputs, and I'll say a few words about those later, and also methods for automated modeling of dynamic systems, which falls within the category of computational scientific discovery.
And as I mentioned, we apply these in the areas of system Biosciences.
Mostly systems, technology and so.
Biology let me even straight first.

The task of equation discovery with an app result from the history of science, the discovery of Kepler's laws of planetary motion, the data in the table below describe the behavior of the moons of Jupiter.
We have observations of the distances between the moons and Jupiter on one hand and the periods of their orbits on the other hand, and from data like this, Kepler derived his law.
Planetary motion, which says that the third degree of the distance between the Moon and Jupiter is proportional to the square of the period of its orbit around around Jupiter.
What we have been working on has been mostly more complicated task, namely the task of finding differential equations rather than algebraic one like the one expressing Kepler's law.
Differential equations describe the behavior of dynamic systems whose state change changes overtime, and here we have an example of such a behavior to populations of boxes.
And here's our observed and the output of.
Equation discovery in this particular case is a set of differential equations that describe this behavior.
So when we simulate this differential equations, we want to obtain behavior which is as similar as possible to the observed data.
So we minimize the error between the simulation and the observed and the observed.
Later.

Now we have been viewing at the task of learning such models in the form of differential equations and some machine learning problem and applying the typical learning S search paradigm, which is central to the field of machine learning and primary issue here has been structuring the space of possible model structures, which is typically very large.
We can derive many many different equation structures that can potentially describe the behavior of the system, so it is.
Quite important on one hand, to limit this space of possible model structures and on the other hand to structure it in a nice way so that it can be traversed in an organized manner.
The second issue which we encounter here is the issue of parameter estimation.
If we take a look at this differential equations here, we actually.
I have some numbers appearing in these equations and we have to estimate these numbers from the measured from the measured data.
Is not an easy or trivial task.

We have been approaching it for quite awhile using so called local derivative based methods based on gradient descent, but these have a number of problems that we have been more recently looking and global or metaheuristic approaches such as Ant colony optimization and differential evolution.
This can then in turn use more complicated functions rather than just.
Minimizing this error between the observed and simulated behavior of the system, they can use more complicated costs.

Now to limit the space of possible model structures we have been considering the use of different types of domain knowledge we saw already in Steve's talk in the morning that already Alan Turing was advocating for the use of such knowledge for solving more complicated problems and we can use different types of domain knowledge such as knowledge about processes that can appear in the domain of study, which we then use as building blocks for.
Constructing more complicated models, we can do model, revision, take existing models and revive them.
Revise them or model completion.
Use partial specifications to complete the models.
So this notion of process models have been.
Very important because it integrates 2 views.
One is the quantitative aspect which we already saw.

The numbers in the differential equations which allow the simulation and the qualitative aspect which actually explains the structure of the model systems in terms of processes and here with different colors.
We have the different processes which are taking place in the ecosystem discovered by this diff.
Special equations, so we represent these.
These very nicely structures the models and allows much easier communication with domain experts in the field of ecology and biology.
Because in the first instance we can just look at the boxes and only at the second instance we can look actually at the numbers and piece of equations which.
Even hidden beneath, so we have been working a lot on inductive process modeling, which now takes observed behavior and domain knowledge and then produces.
Differential equation models.

So the major developments in this area, we have developed a variety of systems starting from simple structures of equations and moving to more complicated ones and looking for different ways to incorporate domain knowledge in the in the process.
Most recently we have working we have been working on this process based models and algorithms to learn such models and applications of this in ecological modeling and systems biology.
So in the.

The logical modeling we have been working on modeling the population dynamics of aquatic ecosystems where a nice library of domain knowledge has been formulated and then used for many different ecosystems.
Variety of lakes in Slovenia and many other countries have been modeled.
In this way and in systems biology, one recent example has been modeling the dynamics of endocytosis.
This is part of the immune response, and it's very important in studying disease, such as tuberculosis and salmonella, which manipulate the human.
The human immune system, and for developing new drugs this process needs.
To be understood now, a variety of research is going on in this area from considering different types of methods for parameter estimation.

Different formalism for representing domain knowledge, developing software platforms for these learning and sample models in the form of differential equations and some new application areas are emerging.
For example synthetic biology.
We have been using equation discovery to propose new designs for biological circuits that achieve certain behaviors.
Now the second line of research was the one on learning predictive model.

The typical situation there is that the input is table of data where the examples of described by a vector of attribute values and we want to predict a single scalar value such as the behavior of the presence of a certain species at a given location.
And.

Now I started my research career working on more complicated versions of the Predictive modeling task where the input is more complicated than just a vector, so this is called structured, structured input and predicting scholar values.
But I have moved more recently towards predicting structured outputs where we want to predict complex things at the right hand side.

For example, similar to the habitat modeling problem where we predict the presence or absence of a species from some environmental characteristics, we might be interested in actually predicting the presence and absence of a whole range of such of such species.
This is predicting the structure of the living community that is present.
At a certain location and we have been using the paradigm of predictive clustering trees for these different types of structured output prediction problems.
The decision trees have the same structure As for the single target prediction, but then the predictions are more complicated.
So here we have predictions for a number of species being present at the site.
Other types of more complex outputs include hierarchical annotations.

These are now more and more common both in annotating text and annotating images, and I do not have time to go into the details, but we can also handle this type of structured outputs, which are represented as hierarchies.
This is for example also very important in predicting gene function, where the gene functions that describe by using high.
Turkeys and.
A third type of structured output is actually time serious, where we can have the time course of the response of jeans to stress, for example, to infection with a certain disease.
So we have examples of such time series.
Some genes become up, regulated and down down, regulated, and others just go up have different patterns of expression.
So this approach that we have predicted clustering trees.
We can handle different types of.

Of outputs and the research topics we have addressed include, besides predictive clustering trees, predictive clustering rules, building ensembles of such treason rules for structured output prediction.
More recently we have been working also on taking out the correlation into account.
If the examples that we consider are not completely independent but placed in some context based spatial or network context, but they are related to other examples.
Most typically these connections are ignored, but there is more and more need to actually consider.

Those connections in the learning process and there's work contacting my group as well, and we actually consider lots of tasks from machine learning now in this context of predicting structured outputs.

For example, feature ranking which has been well studied in the single target case but barely touched upon in the case of structured outputs, we saw several talks on the topic of learning from data streams.
Very few have actually addressed the topic of learning structured output prediction from such large and massive data streams.
And finally, there's been development of ontologies to describe actually investigations in the area of data mining and knowledge discovery to formally represent.
The the tasks, the types of data handled, the types of models considered in.
Data mining now just a few examples of applications and then I will run out of time.
We have been using again structured output prediction for various environmental applications.
You already saw an example of the task of predicting community structure.
We have been also using them in actually environmental monitoring to predict predict the state of the environment from remote sensing data.
For example to predict the forest height and density in a certain area.

So from a small sample, a smaller area using both satellite images and ground truth estimated from 3D data like LIDAR, we learn predictive models and then we apply this to a much larger area and these Maps shown here generated by using machine learning models for predicting the state of.
Forest we have been also applying this methodology to predicting gene function.
You have all heard about genomes.
These are these days becoming easier and easier to sequence.
And there's literally thousands of them now being being generated.
But the task then remains of finding out what the genes within the individual genomes do.
What is their function?
And this can be of different uses in either developing new drugs or in biotechnology manipulating organisms too.
Achieve certain industrial purposes.
So we have been.
Addressing the task of gene function prediction in three model organisms yeast, the plant watercress orbit opsis taliana and the ordinary mouse.
More recently we have actually been addressing also the problem of predicting gene function in a very large number of bacterial genomes using so called phylogenetic profiles.
So each gene is described by the similarity of the gene to jeans in other other genomes, and in this way we have actually predicted gene functions.
For all genes.
In about 1000 of bacterial genomes, this is collaboration with the router Boskovic Institute in Zagreb, and these predictions are available through a web service.
The machine learning technology underneath these ensembles of trees for hierarchical, multi label classification and one of their characteristics is very important.
They actually very efficient and scale very well with both the number of examples on one hand and the complexity of the outputs on the other hand.

Genes can literally have functions from a set of hundreds of thousands of possible functions and most structured output prediction methods do not scale really well when you deal with such complex output spaces, whereas our approach scales really.
Really well.

And the last application I'd like to mention is the one of identifying drug target genes by analyzing data from genomic and compound screens, which can be either high content screens, images being taken of a cellular culture after gene has been silenced, or after our chemical compound has been applied, or flow cytometry, which just give an indication of the increase or decrease in bacterial load.
Another approach we have been using here is finding the relation between.
Gene function and response to stress or infection.
In particular.
We've done this for Mycobacterium leprae.
I thought Lapras city was extinct, but it isn't.

Unfortunately, in this way, by finding the relation between gene function and response to stress in cells exposed to this bacteria, we have identified some interesting candidate genes which meant silenced reduced bacterial load significantly, and these are interesting drug potential drug targets.
So I'd like to conclude that.

Theme that has been actually very important in the in the research contacted by myself and my research group, which has been the interplay of the machine learning methods on one hand and the applications that we have been addressing on the other hand, initially we started working on ecological modelling problems and lots of the methods developed like the equation discovery approaches and methods for predicting multi target multiple targets or hierarchies were developed motivated by.
Modeling population dynamics.

Predicting community structure because then happened, is that these have been general enough to be applied in other areas, such as the prediction of gene function in bioinformatics or modeling the dynamics of cellular processes in systems biology, and we have now been able to go through this cycle several several times and it's proven very, very stimulating and very very rewarding.
With this, I'd like to thank you all for listening and also to.
The members of my research group and long-term collaborators thank you very much.
